title: Episode 95 â€“ John Liu, Founder, Ecosystem Restoration Camps
subtitle: TRANSCRIPT
full_transcript:
[10.1s - 16.2s]: Welcome to the Y-Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,

[16.5s - 22.8s]: we're visiting with John Liu, the founder of ecosystem restoration camps and the chairman

[22.8s - 27.9s]: of its advisory council. Hi, John. Hello, how are you?

[27.9s - 34.6s]: I'm doing great. How are you doing? Not too bad. It's a beautiful day in California.

[35.5s - 40.7s]: Yeah, it looks like a beautiful scene there with folks who are watching the video behind you.

[40.9s - 46.8s]: I can't quite make out of those are mountains or trees or both, but it looks like a beautiful backdrop.

[48.9s - 55.6s]: These are trees, but it isn't a mountainous area. I'm near Santa Cruz. This is the University of

[55.6s - 64.5s]: the trees. It was pioneered by Christopher Hills, who made spirulina long ago, many decades ago.

[64.9s - 73.0s]: He's passed away now, but this is a place where Alan Watts and Timothy Leary and Terrence McKenna

[73.0s - 82.4s]: all hung out. So I'm honored to be here hanging out with and I feel like they're here giving me some

[82.4s - 91.1s]: energy. What a beautiful history there to tap into. John Liu is an ecologist,

[91.5s - 97.3s]: soil scientist, filmmaker and the visionary behind the ecosystem restoration camps movement.

[97.8s - 104.8s]: After working for 15 years as a television producer and cameraman for R.A.I.S.R.G.

[104.8s - 113.5s]: B.S.S.R. ZDF, BBC World and National Geographic Channel, John began to study ecology.

[114.5s - 119.9s]: For the last three decades since working in ecosystem restoration, he obtained numerous

[119.9s - 127.0s]: achievements as a filmmaker, researcher and environmentalist. His documentaries include Greengold,

[127.5s - 134.1s]: Hope in the Changing Climate, and what if we change which won numerous international awards?

[135.6s - 143.1s]: From 2003 to 2006, John was a visiting fellow with the Faculty of Natural Sciences and the

[143.1s - 150.1s]: Faculty of the Built Environment at the University of West of England. In 2006, he was named

[150.8s - 157.2s]: the Rothamstead International Fellow for the Communication of Science. Other positions include

[157.2s - 162.5s]: Senior Research Fellow for the International Union for Conservation of Nature, Associate Professor

[163.1s - 169.1s]: at the George Mason University and Visiting Fellow at Netherlands Institute of Ecology.

[169.9s - 178.2s]: He is also ecosystem ambassador for the Common Land Foundation. Before we dive into our conversation,

[178.5s - 184.9s]: John, which I'm so excited we have the opportunity to share with our why-on-erth community audience.

[185.3s - 189.6s]: I want to point out that my friend, Judith Schwartz, in her recent book,

[190.4s - 195.1s]: Rainier Chronicles, and some folks will remember we had an episode with her recently.

[195.8s - 201.5s]: She refers to you as the Indiana Jones of landscape restoration.

[202.4s - 209.8s]: I thought that was a pretty fun way to kick things off here, John. Clearly, you are helping lead

[209.8s - 217.9s]: a tremendous worldwide movement that is really gaining traction and now substantially scaling.

[218.7s - 224.2s]: Welcome to the show to kick things off. I want to just ask you, John, what is it that ecosystem

[224.2s - 231.0s]: restoration camps is doing and why should we be encouraging other folks to get involved?

[233.9s - 240.3s]: Thank you so much. That was a lovely introduction. I just like to add two things to it if it's okay.

[240.3s - 250.8s]: I worked for TITNERS for CBS News. They basically trained me in professional observation

[250.8s - 258.1s]: and documentation. Also, that I'm the ecosystem ambassador for the Common Land Foundation,

[258.3s - 262.9s]: which now has over 2 million hectares in restoration around the world.

[263.6s - 265.3s]: Thank you. That's beautiful.

[265.3s - 273.9s]: But to address your question, the ecosystem restoration camps movement

[273.9s - 285.4s]: is something that I founded because I had been working in ecosystem restoration after I left

[286.4s - 295.8s]: journalism and the World Bank had asked me to document the restoration of the Lus Plato

[295.8s - 301.1s]: in the upper and middle reaches of the Yellow River in China. This is the cradle of Chinese civilization.

[302.1s - 310.8s]: And over 10 years starting in 1994, I kept going out there and documenting what was happening

[310.8s - 319.8s]: and it was astonishing. A place which was fundamentally degraded and had virtually no vegetation

[319.8s - 327.9s]: and no ecological function was returned to a trajectory which ultimately could lead to

[328.7s - 336.1s]: climax equilibrium again in evolution. So when I saw that, I just basically quit

[337.1s - 343.7s]: journalism and went into study ecology because I thought this is more important than the EGOs,

[343.7s - 354.6s]: the fragile EGOs of politicians. And in doing that, what happened to me was that I realized not only

[354.6s - 361.0s]: do we have the technologies and the understanding of how to restore these systems and that this is

[361.0s - 367.6s]: the absolutely best way to mitigate and adapt to climate changes and to ensure food security and

[367.6s - 377.9s]: reduce the possibility of food insecurity or extreme weather events or climate impacts.

[378.6s - 392.7s]: I found that it also is happening too slow, that the normal mechanisms for giant international

[393.8s - 403.7s]: projects or programs take years to define and then more time to fund and then more time to implement.

[403.7s - 407.8s]: And they're usually a short period of time like three or five years maximum.

[408.9s - 415.9s]: And what I realized was that large numbers of people are not engaged in that. There's a kind of a

[415.9s - 424.2s]: professional class and there's a hierarchy of the powers that be. And these powers that be have

[424.2s - 439.0s]: sort of various types of motives and various types of intentions. And one of the most important

[439.0s - 446.1s]: is to maintain the status quo. And when you're trying to deal with ecosystem restoration,

[446.3s - 453.4s]: you realize, well, the status quo is what caused the degradation and that what's needed to

[453.4s - 462.1s]: restore it is transformational change. And that these institutions may not be in the best shape for

[462.1s - 469.9s]: transformational leading transformational change. And also that it seems to me that the people

[469.9s - 480.8s]: who are available and able to infiltrate moisture, restore ecological function or organic material

[480.8s - 488.0s]: to the soils or propagate and plant out, mainly indigenous and endemic trees and plants

[488.9s - 496.4s]: are not the same people who are walking in marble halls wearing Italian suits and having cufflinks.

[496.8s - 507.3s]: And so the poorest people on the earth seem to be the most available and the most capable of

[507.3s - 515.2s]: doing what needs to be done. But this then becomes a question of value whether whether their lives

[515.2s - 521.4s]: are valued, whether their actions are valued and whether ecological function is valued.

[522.2s - 529.3s]: So we need to have this fundamental shift away from materialism, the idea that more

[530.5s - 539.4s]: manufacturing, more buying and selling is somehow protecting us and not understanding that it's

[539.4s - 547.6s]: air, water, food, biodiversity, soil fertility, climate regulation. And that these are more valuable

[547.6s - 555.2s]: than things. And who can understand that and who can act in that way? They're the poorest people

[555.2s - 560.4s]: on the earth right now who can do that. The people who are benefiting from materialism,

[560.4s - 565.5s]: they have a hard time imagining transformational change.

[566.4s - 570.6s]: Yes, yes, absolutely. Well, and I'm struck. I want to

[572.2s - 585.1s]: mention that the way in which authored Judith Schwartz talks about your work on the

[585.1s - 591.9s]: way folks, if you want, you can go to the y-on-earth.org partners page and click on the link to Chelsea

[591.9s - 602.6s]: Green and use the code yo10, for a 10% discount on her book. But the way she describes the work that

[602.6s - 608.4s]: you've done and that you've documented on the Lois Plateau provides this incredibly pragmatic

[608.4s - 615.4s]: and hopeful vision for what's possible worldwide. John, and I was hoping for our audience who aren't

[615.4s - 622.7s]: yet familiar with your work there. You might create more of a picture for us as to what has occurred

[622.7s - 634.4s]: there over the last many years. Well, when I realized that the giant projects take so long and are

[634.4s - 640.7s]: pretty slow, I started to wonder, is there some way we could engage vast numbers of people

[641.3s - 648.7s]: in ecosystem restoration? And I started having dreams and I had these dreams that were, I was waking

[648.7s - 655.9s]: up in the morning and I had this, I had been clearly processing something overnight while I was

[655.9s - 662.4s]: asleep and I was waking up with this vision of people going camping and restoring the soils and

[662.4s - 669.0s]: restoring the plants and they were all happy and they were all purposeful and they didn't need

[669.0s - 675.0s]: anybody to tell them what to do because they knew what to do. They were studying this and there

[675.0s - 681.0s]: was a sort of, I call it collaborative inquiry for collective intelligence. So everybody was

[681.6s - 690.8s]: studying together as a meta organism instead of as individuals, they were studying together

[691.4s - 697.5s]: and humanity was the only agency that could actually do what needs to be done.

[698.6s - 705.2s]: And what was interesting about this was I rejected it. I said, well, nobody's going to do that.

[705.3s - 710.9s]: I've been making these films about restoration for years and decades and nobody really listens to

[710.9s - 719.5s]: me or very few people are listening. And then, but I kept having the dreams so they were recurrent.

[719.5s - 726.9s]: So I said, well, okay, I'm clearly processing this as I'm sleeping. So maybe I better write about it.

[727.1s - 738.4s]: So I made a few essays you can find one called ecosystem. I think the earth repair

[739.2s - 745.0s]: piece camps in the Permaculture magazine and there was another one in Cosmos Journal.

[745.6s - 752.5s]: And then I also started writing on social media about it. And suddenly something strange happened.

[752.9s - 758.4s]: First tens, then hundreds, then thousands, and then tens of thousands of people started to say,

[758.5s - 764.7s]: well, that's a good idea and we're kind of having that same dream. And so I realized that this wasn't

[764.7s - 774.8s]: just me. This was in the air. This was the time had come for this. And so when a thousand people

[776.2s - 784.5s]: agreed to share 10 euros per month, which is like two cups of coffee at Starbucks now,

[787.6s - 795.3s]: we said, well, okay, if a thousand people are going to share 120 euros per year, 10 euros per month,

[795.4s - 803.2s]: the 120 euros per month, or per year, then we'll have to create a foundation. So we created a foundation

[805.0s - 814.7s]: to accept that money. And in doing that, we started to talk about, well, where should the first camp be?

[815.7s - 825.6s]: And the first camp was built in Spain. And you can go learn about it at ecosystemrestorationcamps.org

[827.2s - 837.1s]: where this is documented. And that was the, so we worked on foundations. And now there are two

[837.1s - 842.3s]: foundations, one in Europe and one in North America, in the United States. And then the second,

[842.5s - 848.7s]: the first camp in Spain and then the second camp in the next year was in Mexico. And then the

[848.7s - 856.8s]: third year, there were 21 camps. And in the fourth year, there are 37 camps around the world in six

[856.8s - 863.9s]: continents. So we started to realize that this is the beginning of a really big movement, which

[863.9s - 872.1s]: engages a large number of people who might not necessarily be involved in ecological restoration.

[872.7s - 878.5s]: And that we're already seeing exponential growth. So in the fifth year and sixth year and

[878.5s - 885.0s]: up to the tenth year, could we end up with millions of people in very many camps all over the world?

[885.3s - 891.0s]: And so I think that's the direction that we're moving in right now. And what's happening there is

[891.0s - 898.0s]: people are happy, just like the dream. The dream is coming true. People are happily working on soil

[898.6s - 907.6s]: fertility and working on propagation and planting out and on watershed management. And it's very

[907.6s - 913.6s]: satisfying to do that. There's maybe nothing more satisfying than seeing a stream or a spring

[913.6s - 922.8s]: return that has been lost. And so we see people working in that area. We are training more and more

[922.8s - 931.5s]: people. There's various aspects of this knowledge hubs that are sharing information, training courses,

[932.0s - 938.1s]: online training courses at camps. So there's so much possibility.

[939.7s - 948.1s]: Yeah, that's so inspiring. And I want to remind folks ecosystem restoration camps.org

[948.7s - 955.7s]: is a wonderful resource with all kinds of opportunities to engage and to learn and to mobilize.

[956.3s - 963.8s]: We'll have this and other links in these show notes, of course. But let me just get right to

[963.8s - 971.9s]: I think a really important question, John. How can folks get involved and support this work that is

[971.9s - 982.3s]: scaling up? Well, there's sort of various ways that they can do this. On the one hand,

[982.3s - 991.9s]: it's possible to join as a supporting member of the camps movement. So this is generally people.

[992.2s - 999.7s]: Actually, we don't have a set thing. Some people are giving five euros. Some people 10 euros.

[999.7s - 1006.4s]: Other people are going to the US 501 C3 and giving dollars. And it could be five dollars or 10

[1006.4s - 1012.5s]: dollars a month. But if you have more money, it could be $50 or $100 a month, whatever you think.

[1014.1s - 1022.6s]: That's one thing. Another way to participate is actually to go to camp. So those people, young

[1022.6s - 1031.0s]: people who might not have any money or people from the developing world to them maybe five or 10

[1031.0s - 1038.3s]: euros is a lot of money. If they're living under a dollar a day or something, then they don't need

[1038.3s - 1043.9s]: to give any money to this. The people who have money can give money and the people who have time

[1043.9s - 1054.5s]: can give time. And so going to camp is a way to learn how to infiltrate and retain moisture in

[1054.5s - 1066.3s]: the soils and how to restore water sheds and how to propagate and plant out the indigenous and

[1066.3s - 1072.4s]: endemic plants. So there's quite a lot to learn. When you start to understand the complexity of this,

[1072.4s - 1080.4s]: it's prodigious. But it's also a great deal of fun to do this and it's really needed.

[1081.9s - 1089.3s]: So as we see this happening, many people perhaps are not thinking about other parts of the world.

[1089.6s - 1094.9s]: They're thinking about where they live. And of course it depends on where you live. So if you live

[1094.9s - 1104.4s]: in Mauritania or Mali or Somalia or Libya or Lebanon or Turkey or Greece or a whole bunch of other

[1104.4s - 1112.2s]: places, even Southern California or all up and down the coast here in the Pacific, if you're

[1112.9s - 1119.4s]: thinking about recurrent drought or you're thinking about wildfires or you're thinking about

[1119.4s - 1127.4s]: mudslides and floods and this sort of thing, then you might want to just deal with your own place.

[1128.2s - 1136.6s]: But if you're in a wonderful place and you're thinking about the Middle East or the dangers around

[1136.6s - 1143.6s]: the world, you have another possibility. Both are possible. You can immediately work in camps

[1144.3s - 1150.3s]: near you and you can work in camps around the world or you can support the whole camps movement

[1150.3s - 1156.9s]: which will just continue to grow. Beautiful. Well, and of course our friends and colleagues

[1157.5s - 1164.5s]: through the Yon Earth community are located throughout the world as we're continuing to grow

[1164.5s - 1170.3s]: globally on this end as well. But at the same time, most of our audience is in the United States and

[1170.4s - 1177.2s]: curious, John. Here in the US, where are there existing camps and or where do you, you know,

[1177.4s - 1184.9s]: foresee new camps potentially emerging that folks closer to this area might engage.

[1186.3s - 1192.0s]: I'm seeing that I'm going into shadow. Should I move a little bit to be in the sunlight or are

[1192.0s - 1199.3s]: you happy with this? I think moving a little for your son is generally a great idea. So if you

[1199.3s - 1204.0s]: would like to, if you're be more comfortable, that sounds good. Thank you. Just a moment.

[1204.9s - 1213.8s]: And one of the things I love about our podcast series is that we do very little post-production work

[1213.8s - 1221.7s]: which allows for two things. One is allows us to get a lot more productivity out of our

[1221.7s - 1228.6s]: modest budget and it also allows for a bit more, I think, candor and in a sense authenticity

[1229.2s - 1235.0s]: in our conversations. And so when this sort of thing occurs, it's fabulous, right? Because

[1235.0s - 1241.0s]: indeed the relative position of the sun from our perspective moves. And to have a little shade

[1241.0s - 1245.8s]: thrown across you by, I imagine a tree or a structure is part of real life.

[1245.8s - 1246.2s]: I think that's a good tree.

[1248.4s - 1255.8s]: Yeah. So, so yeah, John, I was just, I was asking about existing camps and the possibility of

[1255.8s - 1264.0s]: emerging camps here in the United States. Yeah, I think that, you know, there can be camps

[1264.0s - 1272.2s]: everywhere. Basically, it's not about anyone other than the camps themselves choosing where they

[1272.2s - 1280.2s]: are because all of the camps are autonomous, self-organizing and self-governing. So it's not

[1280.2s - 1286.8s]: that we're creating an institution, it's that we're creating a network. And I would, I would call it

[1286.8s - 1295.5s]: more like a mycelial network. One of the wonderful things about Paul Stametz's work with, with

[1295.5s - 1306.7s]: fungi, is the understanding that the mycelial networks from the fungi are like a pathway, a

[1306.7s - 1313.7s]: communications pathway, but actually a physical pathway. So you have very small bacteria,

[1314.4s - 1322.9s]: which is critical for releasing nutrients from geologic materials and making them available to

[1324.0s - 1332.1s]: vascular plants and higher organisms, more complex organisms. But in order for them to, to

[1333.4s - 1341.3s]: actually move those bacteria are sort of stuck in place. But when they touch the mycelial network,

[1341.4s - 1348.0s]: they can go everywhere in the network instantly. So I kind of think of it, I think of the ecosystem

[1348.0s - 1356.5s]: restoration camps in this way, that it's like a mycelial network, which allows for all any, any

[1357.8s - 1365.0s]: breakthrough or accomplishments in any of the camps to transfer to all the other camps instantly.

[1365.5s - 1370.3s]: And when we do that, then we start to see, for instance, I've been working for decades

[1371.3s - 1377.3s]: in this concept of restoration. And I thought, oh, we're going to fail. But then when I had this

[1377.3s - 1384.7s]: dream and started to see it materialize, I thought, well, now that could work because the whole

[1384.7s - 1391.1s]: of humanity could rise up and say, yes, let's, you know, it's not in my interest personally or

[1391.1s - 1401.5s]: I don't profit from restoration personally, but we all benefit. So this is in the collective

[1402.4s - 1410.9s]: interest of all humanity. And I think that's such an easier thing for us to get behind. And it allows

[1410.9s - 1417.5s]: everyone to participate and it allows everyone to participate instantly. Like you don't have to go

[1417.5s - 1424.7s]: get a graduate degree in ecology in order to participate. You can go and there'll be people who

[1424.7s - 1429.9s]: know a lot more than you do if you've just contacted this information and you'll be able to talk with

[1429.9s - 1437.1s]: them and you'll be able to work. And as you do it, you'll know everything because it excuse the

[1437.1s - 1445.6s]: analogy, but it enters from another orifice. And you know, it's, it's, you own, you possess this

[1445.6s - 1454.1s]: information because you, you did it. The healing is in the doing. Not in the thinking or they're

[1454.1s - 1461.0s]: talking about it. It's in the doing. So we need to really get to this place where everyone is

[1461.0s - 1469.5s]: deeply engaged in working for restoration. That is so beautiful. And you know, I imagine that many of

[1469.5s - 1476.6s]: us in the Y on earth community would like to engage further and perhaps even help plant the seeds

[1476.6s - 1483.2s]: of new camps. And so in terms of nuts and bolts, what are the practical steps that we would take

[1483.2s - 1492.3s]: to help establish new camps? Well, I think the first thing might be to

[1492.9s - 1501.8s]: join the ecosystem restoration camps movement as a supporting member at some minimal way. But then

[1501.8s - 1507.0s]: when you do, you're equal to everyone else in the movement. Basically, we're all the same. We're all

[1507.6s - 1515.5s]: sharing a little bit in order to be more powerful than we are as individuals. So what I, what I've

[1515.5s - 1523.0s]: noticed is that together, I think if humanity chooses ecosystem restoration as the central

[1523.0s - 1529.8s]: intention of civilization, there's nothing that can stop us. But if we don't, we're facing quite

[1529.8s - 1541.3s]: serious problems. So having a method that allows a low entry point, but then from there, it's up to you.

[1541.9s - 1546.7s]: What do you want to do? Do you want to go to camp? Do you want to study it? Do you want to

[1547.5s - 1554.4s]: do make new camps? Do you want to? But whatever we do, the first thing is activities.

[1555.3s - 1564.1s]: The first thing is we have to work every day toward increasing soil fertility, increasing carbon

[1564.1s - 1573.4s]: sequestration in the soils in the biomass. And then we need to ensure that the hydrological cycle

[1573.4s - 1580.8s]: is functional. And then we need to understand that the biodiversity is the highest order of ecological

[1580.8s - 1590.0s]: function and is massively complex. It's symbiotic, multidimensional, symbiotic systems, and it's

[1590.0s - 1597.0s]: really, really a high level of understanding. So how can we get this level of understanding?

[1597.4s - 1604.3s]: Okay, you can go and start to study it in graduate school and just go on for years and decades

[1604.3s - 1612.3s]: in this. And it works, ultimately, you understand it. But the best way is to go to the land and

[1612.3s - 1618.7s]: restore the soil and the plants and the biodiversity. And suddenly, you not only know it theoretically,

[1619.0s - 1625.9s]: but you understand exactly how it comes about. And you understand that everyone has a role to play

[1626.6s - 1632.8s]: in this and that we can do this now. We don't need to wait years and decades. We have to do it now

[1632.8s - 1640.1s]: because we're at the crisis point. So the way to make camps is first to have activities.

[1641.0s - 1646.3s]: And then when your activities are, you can't do it alone, there's no way individuals. There's

[1646.3s - 1652.7s]: no way I can restore the earth. There's no way any agency or any institution, the only agency

[1652.7s - 1660.2s]: that can do this is human civilization. So when we understand this and we all work together,

[1660.9s - 1666.1s]: then we can have this effect. And so the more people who are working and what we're trying to do is

[1666.1s - 1673.6s]: create this network that will provide resources, provide encouragement and provide a model

[1674.3s - 1682.9s]: that people can follow. But those models are now morphing into numerous models. So you have models

[1682.9s - 1694.1s]: which are coming from the Morocco and Somalia and Egypt. And you have models which are coming from

[1694.1s - 1702.5s]: Brazil and from Mexico and from Guatemala. And you have models which are coming from India and

[1702.5s - 1711.7s]: Thailand and from Europe and from California. So here in California we've most definitely got to

[1711.7s - 1720.5s]: restore these huge forests which are burning down. And we've got to reverse the trend toward

[1721.0s - 1728.3s]: decade-long drought and desertification. We're changing the climate here. And if we don't

[1728.3s - 1737.4s]: restore it, then it'll continue to decline. But all of that is possible if we work together.

[1738.0s - 1744.7s]: And if we take it outside of the transactional economic system and we say, well, let's just do this

[1744.7s - 1751.7s]: because it's a duty to do this for our children and for future generations. And it's not about

[1751.7s - 1757.7s]: ownership. It's not about like, okay, now we restored the environment. It's mine. You know,

[1757.7s - 1765.9s]: that's ridiculous. It's it belongs to all life. And so when we understand that, then I think we're

[1765.9s - 1771.2s]: at a higher level of consciousness. And when we're at this higher level of consciousness, we're not

[1771.2s - 1777.3s]: really talking about selfish impulses. We're talking about the collective interest of all life,

[1777.7s - 1785.8s]: not only all human beings, but all living things. Yeah, it's so beautiful, John. And it's so exciting as

[1785.8s - 1792.9s]: you and I have been discussing over the last few days, preparing for this interview. There's a lot

[1792.9s - 1799.4s]: of potential opportunity for collaboration between the Y on Earth community and ecosystem restoration

[1799.4s - 1807.2s]: camps. And as I mentioned to you, I'm living at Elk Run Farm here in Colorado, where my friends,

[1807.4s - 1813.7s]: Nick and Marissa are doing amazing work with their nonprofit called Dryland Agro Ecology Research.

[1814.3s - 1820.9s]: And they've already planted over 2000 trees and have done all kinds of swaling work and are doing

[1821.4s - 1826.5s]: holistic grazing work with sheep and running pigs, chickens, ducks through the landscape.

[1827.2s - 1836.7s]: And of course, here in Colorado, much of the terrain is semi-arid. And that means getting a lot of

[1836.7s - 1843.5s]: the water into the ground and keeping it in the soil when we get snows and rains intermittently.

[1843.7s - 1849.5s]: And I just, I get so excited thinking there's a whole lot we can do to collaborate and help scale.

[1849.5s - 1855.5s]: Of course, we'll be developing videos with Nick and Marissa in the coming months that may just be

segments.text: Welcome to the Y-Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,
we're visiting with John Liu, the founder of ecosystem restoration camps and the chairman
of its advisory council. Hi, John. Hello, how are you?
I'm doing great. How are you doing? Not too bad. It's a beautiful day in California.
Yeah, it looks like a beautiful scene there with folks who are watching the video behind you.
I can't quite make out of those are mountains or trees or both, but it looks like a beautiful backdrop.
These are trees, but it isn't a mountainous area. I'm near Santa Cruz. This is the University of
the trees. It was pioneered by Christopher Hills, who made spirulina long ago, many decades ago.
He's passed away now, but this is a place where Alan Watts and Timothy Leary and Terrence McKenna
all hung out. So I'm honored to be here hanging out with and I feel like they're here giving me some
energy. What a beautiful history there to tap into. John Liu is an ecologist,
soil scientist, filmmaker and the visionary behind the ecosystem restoration camps movement.
After working for 15 years as a television producer and cameraman for R.A.I.S.R.G.
B.S.S.R. ZDF, BBC World and National Geographic Channel, John began to study ecology.
For the last three decades since working in ecosystem restoration, he obtained numerous
achievements as a filmmaker, researcher and environmentalist. His documentaries include Greengold,
Hope in the Changing Climate, and what if we change which won numerous international awards?
From 2003 to 2006, John was a visiting fellow with the Faculty of Natural Sciences and the
Faculty of the Built Environment at the University of West of England. In 2006, he was named
the Rothamstead International Fellow for the Communication of Science. Other positions include
Senior Research Fellow for the International Union for Conservation of Nature, Associate Professor
at the George Mason University and Visiting Fellow at Netherlands Institute of Ecology.
He is also ecosystem ambassador for the Common Land Foundation. Before we dive into our conversation,
John, which I'm so excited we have the opportunity to share with our why-on-erth community audience.
I want to point out that my friend, Judith Schwartz, in her recent book,
Rainier Chronicles, and some folks will remember we had an episode with her recently.
She refers to you as the Indiana Jones of landscape restoration.
I thought that was a pretty fun way to kick things off here, John. Clearly, you are helping lead
a tremendous worldwide movement that is really gaining traction and now substantially scaling.
Welcome to the show to kick things off. I want to just ask you, John, what is it that ecosystem
restoration camps is doing and why should we be encouraging other folks to get involved?
Thank you so much. That was a lovely introduction. I just like to add two things to it if it's okay.
I worked for TITNERS for CBS News. They basically trained me in professional observation
and documentation. Also, that I'm the ecosystem ambassador for the Common Land Foundation,
which now has over 2 million hectares in restoration around the world.
Thank you. That's beautiful.
But to address your question, the ecosystem restoration camps movement
is something that I founded because I had been working in ecosystem restoration after I left
journalism and the World Bank had asked me to document the restoration of the Lus Plato
in the upper and middle reaches of the Yellow River in China. This is the cradle of Chinese civilization.
And over 10 years starting in 1994, I kept going out there and documenting what was happening
and it was astonishing. A place which was fundamentally degraded and had virtually no vegetation
and no ecological function was returned to a trajectory which ultimately could lead to
climax equilibrium again in evolution. So when I saw that, I just basically quit
journalism and went into study ecology because I thought this is more important than the EGOs,
the fragile EGOs of politicians. And in doing that, what happened to me was that I realized not only
do we have the technologies and the understanding of how to restore these systems and that this is
the absolutely best way to mitigate and adapt to climate changes and to ensure food security and
reduce the possibility of food insecurity or extreme weather events or climate impacts.
I found that it also is happening too slow, that the normal mechanisms for giant international
projects or programs take years to define and then more time to fund and then more time to implement.
And they're usually a short period of time like three or five years maximum.
And what I realized was that large numbers of people are not engaged in that. There's a kind of a
professional class and there's a hierarchy of the powers that be. And these powers that be have
sort of various types of motives and various types of intentions. And one of the most important
is to maintain the status quo. And when you're trying to deal with ecosystem restoration,
you realize, well, the status quo is what caused the degradation and that what's needed to
restore it is transformational change. And that these institutions may not be in the best shape for
transformational leading transformational change. And also that it seems to me that the people
who are available and able to infiltrate moisture, restore ecological function or organic material
to the soils or propagate and plant out, mainly indigenous and endemic trees and plants
are not the same people who are walking in marble halls wearing Italian suits and having cufflinks.
And so the poorest people on the earth seem to be the most available and the most capable of
doing what needs to be done. But this then becomes a question of value whether whether their lives
are valued, whether their actions are valued and whether ecological function is valued.
So we need to have this fundamental shift away from materialism, the idea that more
manufacturing, more buying and selling is somehow protecting us and not understanding that it's
air, water, food, biodiversity, soil fertility, climate regulation. And that these are more valuable
than things. And who can understand that and who can act in that way? They're the poorest people
on the earth right now who can do that. The people who are benefiting from materialism,
they have a hard time imagining transformational change.
Yes, yes, absolutely. Well, and I'm struck. I want to
mention that the way in which authored Judith Schwartz talks about your work on the
way folks, if you want, you can go to the y-on-earth.org partners page and click on the link to Chelsea
Green and use the code yo10, for a 10% discount on her book. But the way she describes the work that
you've done and that you've documented on the Lois Plateau provides this incredibly pragmatic
and hopeful vision for what's possible worldwide. John, and I was hoping for our audience who aren't
yet familiar with your work there. You might create more of a picture for us as to what has occurred
there over the last many years. Well, when I realized that the giant projects take so long and are
pretty slow, I started to wonder, is there some way we could engage vast numbers of people

asleep and I was waking up with this vision of people going camping and restoring the soils and
restoring the plants and they were all happy and they were all purposeful and they didn't need
anybody to tell them what to do because they knew what to do. They were studying this and there
was a sort of, I call it collaborative inquiry for collective intelligence. So everybody was
studying together as a meta organism instead of as individuals, they were studying together
and humanity was the only agency that could actually do what needs to be done.
And what was interesting about this was I rejected it. I said, well, nobody's going to do that.
I've been making these films about restoration for years and decades and nobody really listens to
me or very few people are listening. And then, but I kept having the dreams so they were recurrent.
So I said, well, okay, I'm clearly processing this as I'm sleeping. So maybe I better write about it.
So I made a few essays you can find one called ecosystem. I think the earth repair
piece camps in the Permaculture magazine and there was another one in Cosmos Journal.
And then I also started writing on social media about it. And suddenly something strange happened.
First tens, then hundreds, then thousands, and then tens of thousands of people started to say,
well, that's a good idea and we're kind of having that same dream. And so I realized that this wasn't
just me. This was in the air. This was the time had come for this. And so when a thousand people
agreed to share 10 euros per month, which is like two cups of coffee at Starbucks now,
we said, well, okay, if a thousand people are going to share 120 euros per year, 10 euros per month,
the 120 euros per month, or per year, then we'll have to create a foundation. So we created a foundation
to accept that money. And in doing that, we started to talk about, well, where should the first camp be?
And the first camp was built in Spain. And you can go learn about it at ecosystemrestorationcamps.org
where this is documented. And that was the, so we worked on foundations. And now there are two
foundations, one in Europe and one in North America, in the United States. And then the second,
the first camp in Spain and then the second camp in the next year was in Mexico. And then the
third year, there were 21 camps. And in the fourth year, there are 37 camps around the world in six
continents. So we started to realize that this is the beginning of a really big movement, which
engages a large number of people who might not necessarily be involved in ecological restoration.
And that we're already seeing exponential growth. So in the fifth year and sixth year and
up to the tenth year, could we end up with millions of people in very many camps all over the world?
And so I think that's the direction that we're moving in right now. And what's happening there is
people are happy, just like the dream. The dream is coming true. People are happily working on soil
fertility and working on propagation and planting out and on watershed management. And it's very
satisfying to do that. There's maybe nothing more satisfying than seeing a stream or a spring
return that has been lost. And so we see people working in that area. We are training more and more
people. There's various aspects of this knowledge hubs that are sharing information, training courses,
online training courses at camps. So there's so much possibility.
Yeah, that's so inspiring. And I want to remind folks ecosystem restoration camps.org
is a wonderful resource with all kinds of opportunities to engage and to learn and to mobilize.
We'll have this and other links in these show notes, of course. But let me just get right to
I think a really important question, John. How can folks get involved and support this work that is
scaling up? Well, there's sort of various ways that they can do this. On the one hand,
it's possible to join as a supporting member of the camps movement. So this is generally people.
Actually, we don't have a set thing. Some people are giving five euros. Some people 10 euros.
Other people are going to the US 501 C3 and giving dollars. And it could be five dollars or 10
dollars a month. But if you have more money, it could be $50 or $100 a month, whatever you think.
That's one thing. Another way to participate is actually to go to camp. So those people, young

So as we see this happening, many people perhaps are not thinking about other parts of the world.
They're thinking about where they live. And of course it depends on where you live. So if you live

I think that's a good tree.
Yeah. So, so yeah, John, I was just, I was asking about existing camps and the possibility of
emerging camps here in the United States. Yeah, I think that, you know, there can be camps
